awd_titl_txt: Aspects of Unipotent Dynamics on Homogenous Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Many questions in number theory and geometry involve multiple infinite groups of symmetries in their structures. Exploring the interactions between these groups of symmetries using ideas from dynamical systems, applied to suitably created algebraic models, is at the core of mathematical work involved in this project. The primary goal of the project is to make new observations that relate, and to develop new techniques applicable for solving, a variety of dynamical, number theoretical, and geometrical problems. The work combines concepts from several different areas of mathematics, and it is anticipated that the project will build conceptual bridges between these different disciplines. Graduate students and post-doctoral researchers will participate in the research project, preparing them to work on some of the forefront areas of mathematics.

The investigator and his graduate students will study a wide range of dynamical questions on unipotent flows on homogeneous spaces that arise from number theoretic or geometrical questions. The project investigates four types of problems: (1) Describe closures of unipotent orbits and totally geodesic immersions in infinite-volume geometrically-finite hyperbolic manifolds; (2) Control the non-divergence rate of unipotent trajectories or expanding translates of short unipotent curves under suitable Diophantine conditions on the base point; (3) Find geometric conditions under which expanding translates of a curve in a homogeneous space are uniformly distributed in the limit; (4) Compute Hausdorff dimensions of the sets of points with specified excursion rates for flows on non-compact homogeneous spaces. This study will combine techniques from various areas of mathematics, including dynamical systems, Lie groups, representation theory, algebraic geometry, probability theory, number theory, and combinatorics. The research aims to obtain new results and develop new techniques of dynamical, number theoretical, and combinatorial nature.

por.por_cntn:
Real numbers and vectors can be described via their approximations by rational numbers or rational vectors. Rationals have numerators and denominators; for a better approximation, one needs larger denominators. The Diophantine property of a number or a vector quantifies the relation between the closeness of approximations and the sizes of the denominators. We study this Diophantine property of vectors via the dynamical model of flows on homogeneous spaces of Lie groups. In the dynamical model, one analyzes how frequently certain flow lines visit different regions of the homogeneous space over a long time period.

In this project, we developed new techniques and ideas to gain deeper insights into the asymptotical dynamical behavior of an individual trajectory, or trajectories of a collection of points under the flow. We found and utilized new connections between the Diophantine properties of the vectors and the dynamical behavior of the corresponding trajectories in the homogeneous sapces. Our new dynamical results have yielded resolution of some long standing open questions on Diophantine approximation. We also quantified the sizes of sets of vectors with some specific Diophantine properties or the correspoinding asymptotic properties of the flow lines.

The theme of our work has been exploring the interconnections between number theory and homogenous dynamics via observing new symmetries. The dynamical and group theoretical ideas developed through this project also have the potential to be used in very different fields, like theoretical physics. 

A significant aspect of this project was training doctoral students and post-doctoral fellows. Their participation in the problems considered in this project allowed them to conduct non-trivial research work in this rich and growing field, which involves interactions between diverse areas of mathematics, like dynamical systems, number theory, group theory, and algebraic geometry. These students and graduates are on successful academic career paths at the US and international universities.
